<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 186, 171, 201]]<|/det|>
# PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 206, 366, 222]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 Multiple Choice (Extended)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[780, 185, 905, 200]]<|/det|>
0625/22  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 207, 905, 222]]<|/det|>
May/June 2019  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[814, 228, 905, 242]]<|/det|>
45 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 248, 590, 291]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Multiple Choice Answer Sheet Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 311, 388, 328]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 342, 237, 357]]<|/det|>
Write in soft pencil.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 357, 504, 372]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 372, 892, 401]]<|/det|>
Write your name, centre number and candidate number on the Answer Sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 400, 383, 415]]<|/det|>
DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 429, 892, 459]]<|/det|>
There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions. For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 458, 890, 475]]<|/det|>
Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the separate Answer Sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 488, 556, 504]]<|/det|>
Read the instructions on the Answer Sheet very carefully.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 517, 764, 533]]<|/det|>
Each correct answer will score one mark. A mark will not be deducted for a wrong answer.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 533, 465, 548]]<|/det|>
Any rough working should be done in this booklet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 549, 359, 564]]<|/det|>
Electronic calculators may be used.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 564, 630, 579]]<|/det|>
Take the weight of \(1.0\mathrm{kg}\) to be \(10\mathrm{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 10\mathrm{m / s}^2\) ).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 70, 737, 91]]<|/det|>

<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 125, 390, 144]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 152, 134, 170]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 151, 425, 170]]<|/det|>
the thickness of a sheet of paper

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 178, 134, 196]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 178, 406, 196]]<|/det|>
the volume of a sheet of paper

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 222, 96, 241]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 222, 490, 241]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 252, 880, 272]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 284, 361, 303]]<|/det|>

<label>11</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 559, 826, 578]]<|/det|>
A force \(F\) acts on a body and the body moves a distance \(d\) in the direction of the force.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 590, 529, 607]]<|/det|>
Which expression for the work done \(W\) is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 618, 133, 636]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 618, 218, 636]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[473, 618, 568, 636]]<|/det|>

<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[648, 618, 744, 636]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>

<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 301, 490, 319]]<|/det|>
decreasing the surface area of the stone

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 327, 134, 346]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 327, 423, 346]]<|/det|>

using a liquid with a lower density

<label>14</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 422, 524, 441]]<|/det|>
At room temperature, iron is difficult to compress.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 453, 630, 472]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 483, 687, 502]]<|/det|>
Which comparison of the structures of iron and oxygen explains this?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 512, 133, 530]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 512, 465, 530]]<|/det|>
The iron particles are closer together.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 540, 133, 558]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 540, 480, 558]]<|/det|>
The iron particles have a greater mass.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 567, 133, 585]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 567, 465, 585]]<|/det|>

<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 593, 579, 611]]<|/det|>
The iron particles have less average kinetic energy.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 109, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|> A night storage heater contains a large block of material that is heated electrically during the night. During the day the block cools down, releasing thermal energy into the room. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[413, 114, 581, 262]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 274, 920, 308]]<|/det|> Which thermal capacity and which night-time temperature increase will cause the most energy to be stored by the block? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 319, 562, 465]]<|/det|>
thermal capacity of blocknight-time temperature increase
Alargelarge
Blargesmall
Csmalllarge
Dsmallsmall
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 492, 104, 510]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 492, 920, 526]]<|/det|> 100 g of water at \(25^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\) is poured into an insulated cup. 50 g of ice at \(0^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\) is added to the water. The water is stirred until the temperature of the water has fallen to \(0^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 537, 361, 556]]<|/det|> 18 g of ice remains unmelted. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 570, 514, 587]]<|/det|> The specific heat capacity of water is \(4.2 \text{ J} /\text{ g} ^{\circ}\text{ C}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 599, 787, 617]]<|/det|> Which value does this experiment give for the specific latent heat of fusion of ice? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 628, 133, 645]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 628, 220, 645]]<|/det|> 210 J/g <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 628, 291, 645]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[310, 628, 390, 645]]<|/det|> 330 J/g <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[448, 628, 460, 645]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[475, 628, 552, 645]]<|/det|> 580 J/g <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 628, 636, 645]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[643, 628, 720, 645]]<|/det|> 770 J/g <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 673, 106, 691]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 673, 920, 706]]<|/det|> The handle of a metal saucepan is made of plastic. As the saucepan heats up, the handle gets warmer. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 718, 376, 736]]<|/det|> Which statement explains this? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 747, 133, 765]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 747, 675, 765]]<|/det|> Molecules of the plastic radiate their energy to other molecules. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 774, 131, 791]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 774, 841, 791]]<|/det|> Molecules of the plastic vibrate more and pass on their energy to nearby molecules. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 800, 131, 817]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 800, 787, 817]]<|/det|> The free electrons in the plastic transfer the thermal energy along the handle. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 826, 133, 844]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 826, 688, 844]]<|/det|> The heated molecules very slowly move along the plastic handle.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 109, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 408, 88]]<|/det|> The metal surface of a kettle is hot. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 102, 885, 120]]<|/det|> What happens to the cool air outside the kettle when it comes into contact with the hot kettle? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 131, 134, 147]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 131, 556, 147]]<|/det|> The density of the air decreases and the air falls. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 157, 133, 175]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 157, 561, 175]]<|/det|> The density of the air decreases and the air rises. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 184, 131, 202]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 183, 549, 200]]<|/det|> The density of the air increases and the air falls. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 210, 133, 227]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 209, 556, 225]]<|/det|> The density of the air increases and the air rises. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 254, 107, 272]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 253, 843, 271]]<|/det|> Vacuum flasks usually have silvered walls that help to keep the contents of the flask hot. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 284, 346, 301]]<|/det|> Why are the walls silvered? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 312, 134, 330]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 312, 599, 330]]<|/det|> to absorb thermal energy from the air around the flask <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 339, 134, 356]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 339, 559, 356]]<|/det|> to increase the rate of convection inside the flask <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 365, 134, 383]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 365, 616, 382]]<|/det|> to reduce energy loss to the surroundings by conduction <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 392, 133, 409]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 392, 526, 408]]<|/det|> to reflect thermal radiation back into the flask <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 434, 106, 453]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 434, 546, 453]]<|/det|> When water waves pass through a gap they diffract. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 465, 601, 482]]<|/det|> The diagrams show wavefronts approaching a narrow gap. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 494, 489, 511]]<|/det|> In which diagram will the diffraction be least? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 354, 104, 371]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 354, 920, 387]]<|/det|> An experiment is carried out to measure the radiation from a radioactive source that has a half-life of 10 minutes. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 399, 789, 417]]<|/det|> The source is placed close to a detector that is connected to a counter, as shown. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 426, 834, 515]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 528, 589, 546]]<|/det|> The average background count-rate is 20 counts/minute. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 559, 878, 577]]<|/det|> At the start of the experiment, the count-rate recorded by the counter is 1000 counts/minute. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 590, 450, 607]]<|/det|> What is the count-rate 10 minutes later? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 617, 139, 635]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 618, 312, 635]]<|/det|> 490 counts/ minute <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 644, 139, 662]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 644, 312, 662]]<|/det|> 500 counts/ minute <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 670, 139, 688]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 670, 312, 688]]<|/det|> 510 counts/ minute <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 698, 139, 715]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 698, 312, 715]]<|/det|> 530 counts/ minute <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 839, 920, 871]]<|/det|> Permission to reproduce items where third-party owned material protected by copyright is included has been sought and cleared where possible.
